name: Who Has Got Your Back?
description:
Step into the enchanting world of mythical beings with this special trivia session inspired by our exhibition 'In Celestial Company'. Discover the fascinating stories behind divine companions like Garuda, Mooshika, Airavata, and the many other fantastical creatures that journey alongside gods and goddesses.

This isn't your typical trivia night. The questions are designed to be accessible and engaging, with clues and hints that help you piece together the answers. You don't need to be a mythology scholar—just bring your curiosity and a problem-solving spirit!

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Sign Language 101
description:
Learn a new language with your family! 

Join our Indian Sign Language session for beginners hosted by Madhur Arora from the MAP team. Learn words in sign language related to family, art, culture and more. Connect with the deaf community, learn to communicate beyond words, and pick up a valuable skill.

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Drum Jam
description:
Drum up some excitement! Join us for a high-energy Drum Jam session, specially designed for kids aged 10-15. Let loose, make some noise, and groove to the rhythm with fellow young music enthusiasts.  This promises to be a fun-filled experience that will keep your energy pumping and your spirits high. Come drum, dance, and make some unforgettable memories! This event is in collaboration with Beats Guru.

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Bangalore Storytellers
description:
In collaboration with the Bangalore Storytelling Society, this event is an immersive storytelling experience. Join us to meet the storytellers, dressed in character, as they regale you with stories inspired by our artworks. Don't miss this unique opportunity to bond with your loved ones and get lost in the world of storytelling!

This is a drop-in session. Registration is not required.

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Material Matters
description:
Come experience an exciting walkthrough of our  exhibition VISIBLE/INVISIBLE where we highlight the many different materials used by artists to bring their artistic vision to life! This session will be followed by a workshop where participants are encouraged to play with a range of materials to create artworks in response to the ones they have seen in the exhibition.

This event is a part of Family Day.

name: Write from Art, Write from Story
description:
Explore the multifaceted world of artist and writer Ram Kumar through a unique creative writing workshop, in conjunction with our exhibition Shape of a Thought:Letters from Ram Kumar  - inviting observation, reflection, and profound emotional resonance.

This workshop draws inspiration from two powerful sources within Ram Kumar's creative universe. Participants will engage with his abstract and cityscape paintings on display, letting their emotional depth spark creative expression, while also exploring his short stories—available in translation within the gallery—with their unflinching social criticism and bold narrative voice.

Over two days, Out of Print founder and editor Indira Chandrasekhar will guide participants through exercises that deepen artistic observation and literary craft, creating a dialogue between visual and written expression.

name: In & Out of the Frame
description:
Join us for a walkthrough of our permanent exhibition with Senior Archivist from the Archives at NCBS, Anjali Ramachandran.

When we encounter artworks at a museum, we make meaning either through the work itself, its setting, or through labels that accompany them. Another way to read an artwork is to look for what's not in the 'frame'—to explore the circumstances of its creation and the use of the artwork, rather than just the artwork itself.

In this guided walk, you will get to explore our permanent exhibition, VISIBLE/INVISIBLE: Representation of Women through the MAP Collection, through the lens of an archivist. We will discuss the maker, the purpose, a specific object's relation to others, and the broader social and historical environment in which the artworks were created. In archival sciences, this is called contextualisation, where archivists understand records through the varied ways in which memories (remembered or in recorded acts) have been transmitted over time and space with numerous inscriptions, transmissions, and omissions.

Although it sounds technical, the process itself can be disruptive and playful. It involves gossip, peeking behind the curtain, and an understanding of the complex process of making art!

name: Pottery House
description:
Join us for a screening of Pottery House by Mansi Bhatt, an experimental film that explores memory, heritage, and architecture through the remains of a demolished home on the Khodiyar Pottery Estate. In this layered journey, Mansi blurs, overlays, and sutures objects and images, reanimating her family’s former house until its curves and textures become tangible once more. The film asks: what happens when a place transforms into a state of irrecognition—or disappears altogether along with the boundaries that once defined it?

Following the screening, join architect and theorist Kaiwan Mehta for a discussion on the intersections of space, memory, and cultural heritage. Together, they will reflect on how architecture shapes human experience and the importance of recognising built environments as vessels of history and imagination.

This programme is presented in celebration of World Architecture Day, 6 October.

name: Chippi the Chipkali
description:
One day, Chippi the baby lizard is shooed away while playing. People think it is scary and ugly. Shocked by this, Chippi loses her tail and everyone starts teasing her by calling her names, as she is now without a tail. She feels very sorry for herself and goes  into a dark corner, crying. She knows that she has to get a tail. So what does she do to get her tail? Will she ever get her tail back? Will she become beautiful again? Find out the rest of Chippi’s story and join us for this performance by Ranga Shankara AHA!

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Scavenger Hunt
description:
Turn the museum into your playground with our lively scavenger hunt! Perfect for all ages, this adventure will lead you through galleries and hidden corners using fun  clues and challenges. Solve riddles, spot details, and uncover secrets behind artworks as you race to the finish.

This event is part of the Family Day.

name: Wheel of Feelings
description:
Ever wondered what Blue feels, or Red might say? Step into a world where art meets emotions, and allow colours to tell you their stories. 

Join us for an engaging event where participants will be gently guided by a set of prompts and introduced to the book When The Crayons Quit, allowing them to personally connect with different colours using emotions. This will be followed by a guided walk of MAP’s ongoing exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar to seek inspirations from the use of colours in the artworks on display, before creating an artwork of their own!

This event is a part of Family Day.

name: Norma Rae (1979)
description:
Norma Rae©️1979 Twentieth Century Fox Film Corporation. All Rights Reserved.

In collaboration with Bangalore Film Forum (BFF), MAP is excited to announce the screening of Norma Rae directed by Martin Ritt. Based on the true story of a textile worker who becomes involved in union organizing in the American South, Norma Rae is an iconic film about labour struggles. It sheds light on the harsh working conditions of mill workers and the personal cost of organizing. 

Following the screening, join us for a walkthrough of the exhibition Ticket, Tika, Chaap, which offers a deep dive into the often-overlooked world of textile labels in MAP’s collection.

Inspired by the themes of Norma Rae, we will reflect on the labour, craft, and histories embedded in these small yet powerful objects.

name: Up, Close & Centre
description: This session of Up, Close and Center looks at one of the artworks by the renowned modernist painter Ram Kumar from the exhibition Shape of a Thought: Letters from Ram Kumar by curator Priya Chauhan.

name: The Great Tikat Hunt
description:
Unleash your inner detective as you embark on a thrilling quest to find hidden clues scattered throughout the exhibition Ticket Tika Chaap. These intricately designed labels carry stories within them. This is your chance to decode its narrative. The more clues you find, the closer you get to victory. Are you ready to take on the challenge? Let the hunt begin!

This event is part of the Family Day.
